<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
<A HREF="#A16-4734_110K_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS" TITLE="CLICK TO GO TO TABLE OF CONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	General
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We provide valuable molecular diagnostic solutions and comprehensive clinical support for the highest quality of care.&#160; We specialize in pre-implantation genetic screening, miscarriage analysis, prenatal and pediatric healthcare, offering DNA-based testing for the detection of genetic abnormalities beyond what can be identified through traditional methodologies.&#160; We perform genetic testing utilizing a variety of advanced cytogenomic techniques, including chromosomal microarray, or CMA, standardized and customized fluorescent in-situ hybridization, or FISH, and high resolution karyotyping.&#160; We emphasize support for healthcare professionals, to ensure data understanding and communication of results to patients.&#160; We deliver high-technology driven answers, with a high degree of assistance for the ordering physician and staff
</FONT>
	.&#160; Our clinical lab and corporate offices are located in Irvine, California.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We also own a one-third minority interest in Leuchemix,&nbsp;Inc. (&#147;Leuchemix&#148;), a private drug development company focused on developing a series of compounds to address a number of oncology-related diseases.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Liquidity
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, the combination of cash, cash equivalents and short term investments totaled $3.9 million.&#160; We believe our year-end cash balances will be sufficient to meet our expected cash requirements for current operations into the third quarter of 2016.&#160; In order for us to continue as a going concern beyond this point and ultimately to achieve profitability, we may be required to obtain capital from external sources, increase revenues and reduce operating costs.&#160; However, there can be no assurances that our operations will become profitable or that external sources of financing, including the issuance of debt and/or equity securities, will be available at times and at terms acceptable to us, or at all.&#160; The issuance of additional equity or convertible debt securities will also cause dilution to our shareholders.&#160; If external financing sources are not available or are inadequate to fund our operations, we will be required to reduce operating costs, including research projects and personnel, which could jeopardize our future strategic initiatives and business plans.&#160; See the Liquidity and Capital Resources section below as well as Notes 1 and 13 to our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report for additional discussion of these matters.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Overview of Recent Business Activities
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	During 2015, our business activities were driven primarily by commercialization efforts for our suite of molecular diagnostic tests, expansion of our test menu and by the infusion of additional capital.&#160; For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, our operating activities included the recognition of $10.1 million of total revenues, which increased by $2.0 million from 2014, due primarily to increased volumes of microarray diagnostic tests performed, particularly in the reproductive health testing market, which includes testing volumes from prenatal, miscarriage analysis and pre-implantation genetic screening (or &#147;PGS&#148;) diagnostic tests.&#160; Volumes from our reproductive health testing services increased by 40% in 2015 compared to from 2014, and total microarray testing increased by 22% in 2015 compared to 2014.&#160; Our net loss from operations in 2015 decreased over 2014 primarily due to increased revenues and decreased operating expenses as a result of reduced litigation expenses, partially offset by increased cost of services from higher testing volumes as well as from higher sales and marketing expenses from increased sales and sales-support staff.&#160; The decrease in our net loss attributable to common stockholders was partially offset by $1.1 million of deemed dividends incurred from the issuance of Series&nbsp;E convertible preferred stock and modification of Series&nbsp;E warrants, discussed further below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	In February&nbsp;2015, we executed a registered direct offering with certain accredited institutional pre-existing investors for the issuance of Series&nbsp;E convertible preferred stock, common stock and warrants to purchase common stock (the &#147;Series&nbsp;E Financing&#148;), resulting in net proceeds to us of approximately $4.7 million.&#160; Substantially concurrently with the closing of the Series&nbsp;E Financing, we entered into a separate securities purchase agreement with selected accredited institutional pre-existing investors to sell warrants to purchase our common stock, pending stockholders&#146; approval that was obtained on April&nbsp;28, 2015 to increase our authorized common stock from 25 million shares to 50 million shares.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Critical Accounting Policies
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	Our consolidated financial statements are prepared in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.&#160; In preparing these financial statements, we make assumptions, judgments and estimates that can have a significant impact on amounts reported in our financial statements. We base our assumptions, judgments and estimates on historical experience and various other factors that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances. Actual results could differ materially from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. On a regular basis we evaluate our assumptions, judgments and estimates and make changes accordingly.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
	26
<A NAME="A16-4734_110K_HTM_PB_26_121214_5796">
</A>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<HR SIZE="3" WIDTH="100%" NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="COLOR:#010101;">
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='26',FILE='C:\JMS\105568\16-4734-1\TASK7786517\4734-1-BM.HTM',USER='105568',CD='FEB 18 07:02 2016' -->
<A NAME="eolPage27"></A>
<BR CLEAR="ALL" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS;">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
<A HREF="#A16-4734_110K_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS" TITLE="CLICK TO GO TO TABLE OF CONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We believe that, of the significant accounting policies discussed in Note 2 to our consolidated financial statements, the following accounting policies require our most difficult, subjective or complex judgments:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	revenue recognition and estimates for contractual allowances;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	accounting for stock-based compensation;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	accounting for derivative financial instruments;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	fair value measurements; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	accounting for income taxes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We discuss below the critical accounting assumptions, judgments and estimates associated with these policies.&#160; Historically, our assumptions, judgments and estimates relative to our critical accounting policies have not differed materially from actual results. For further information on our critical accounting policies, refer to Note&nbsp;2 to our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.3PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Revenue Recognition
</FONT>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.3PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	As described below, significant management judgments must be made and used in connection with the revenue recognized in any accounting period.&#160; Material differences may result in the amount and timing of revenue recognized or deferred for any period if management made different judgments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We recognize revenue when (i)&nbsp;persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, (ii)&nbsp;delivery has occurred or services have been performed, (iii)&nbsp;amounts are fixed or determinable and (iv)&nbsp;collectability of amounts is reasonably assured.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	Service revenues from providing diagnostic tests are recognized when the testing process is complete and test results are reported to the ordering physician or clinic. These diagnostic services are billed to various payors, including commercial insurance companies, healthcare institutions, government payors including various state Medicaid programs, and individuals. We report revenues from contracted payors based on a contractual rate, or in the case of state Medicaid contracts, published fee schedules for our tests. We report revenues from non-contracted payors based on the amounts expected to be collected. The differences between the amounts billed and the amounts expected to be collected from non-contracted payors are recorded as contractual allowances to arrive at net recognized revenues. The expected revenues from non-contracted payors are based on the historical collection experience of each payor or payor group, as appropriate, and also take into account recent collection trends. In each reporting period, we review our historical collection experience for non-contracted payors and adjust our expected revenues for current and subsequent periods accordingly. We also recognize additional revenue from actual cash payments that exceed amounts initially recognized in the period the payments are received.&#160; Because a substantial portion of our revenues is from non-contracted third-party payors, it is likely that we will be required to make adjustments to accounting estimates with respect to contractual allowances in the future, which may positively or adversely affect our results of operations.&#160; In all cases described above, we report revenues net of any applicable statutory taxes collected from customers, as applicable.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation
</FONT>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	The compensation cost for all employee stock-based awards is measured at the grant date, based on the fair value of the award, and is recognized as an expense, on a straight-line basis, over the employee&#146;s requisite service period (generally the vesting period of the equity award) which is generally four years.&#160; The fair value of each stock option award is estimated on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option valuation model.&#160; The fair value of each restricted stock unit (&#147;RSU&#148;) award is based on the number of shares granted and the closing price of our common stock as reported on the Nasdaq Capital Market on the date of grant.&#160; Stock-based compensation expense is recognized only for those awards that are expected to vest using an estimated forfeiture rate.&#160; We estimate pre-vesting option forfeitures at the time of grant and reflect the impact of estimated pre-vesting option forfeitures as a component of the expense recognized
</FONT>
	.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Accounting for Derivative Financial Instruments
</FONT>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We evaluate financial instruments for freestanding or embedded derivatives.&#160; Derivative instruments that do not qualify for permanent equity classification are recorded as liabilities at fair value, with changes in value recognized as other income (expense) in the consolidated statements of operations in the period of change.&#160; Derivative warrant liabilities are categorized as either short-term or long-term based upon management&#146;s estimates as to when the derivative instrument may be realized.&#160;
</FONT>
	Management judgment is required in identifying derivative instruments and whether or not such instruments should be classified as liabilities or as a component of permanent equity based upon interpretations of existing accounting literature.&#160; Also, management judgment is required in determining the assumptions and valuation methods to be used for valuing the derivatives.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
	27
<A NAME="A16-4734_110K_HTM_PB_27_121307_2897">
</A>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<HR SIZE="3" WIDTH="100%" NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="COLOR:#010101;">
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='27',FILE='C:\JMS\105568\16-4734-1\TASK7786517\4734-1-BM.HTM',USER='105568',CD='FEB 18 07:02 2016' -->
<A NAME="eolPage28"></A>
<BR CLEAR="ALL" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS;">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
<A HREF="#A16-4734_110K_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS" TITLE="CLICK TO GO TO TABLE OF CONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	If actual results differ from these estimates, the future impact on our consolidated financial position and results of operations could be significant.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Fair Value Measurements
</FONT>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We measure fair value as an exit price, representing the amount that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants.&#160; As such, fair value is a market-based measurement that is determined based on assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or liability.&#160; We utilize a three-tier fair value hierarchy, which prioritizes the inputs used in measuring fair value as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT 81.0PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-63.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	Level 1:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Observable market inputs such as quoted prices in active markets;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT 81.0PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-63.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	Level 2:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Observable market inputs, other than the quoted prices in active markets, that are observable either directly or indirectly; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT 81.35PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-63.35PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	Level 3:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Unobservable inputs where there is little or no market data, which require the reporting entity to develop its own assumptions
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT 17.4PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Accounting for Income Taxes
</FONT>
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	We recognize income taxes on an accrual basis based on tax positions taken or expected to be taken in our tax returns.&#160; A tax position is defined as a position in a previously filed tax return or a position expected to be taken in a future tax filing that is reflected in measuring current or deferred income tax assets and liabilities.&#160; Tax positions are recognized only when it is more likely than not (i.e., likelihood of greater than 50%), based on technical merits, that the position would be sustained upon examination by taxing authorities.&#160; Tax positions that meet the more likely than not threshold are measured using a probability-weighted approach as the largest amount of tax benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized upon settlement.&#160; Income taxes are accounted for using an asset and liability approach that requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been recognized in our financial statements or tax returns. A valuation allowance is established to reduce deferred tax assets if all, or some portion, of such assets will more than likely not be realized.&#160; Should they occur, our policy is to classify interest and penalties related to tax positions as income tax expense.&#160; Since our inception, no such interest or penalties have been incurred, however.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<A NAME="FIS_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Comparison of the Results of Operations
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_5"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	Revenues and Cost of Revenues
</FONT>
	(dollars in thousands):
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<TABLE BORDER="0" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="76%" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;MARGIN-LEFT:20.15PT;">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="44%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="PADDING:0IN 0IN 0IN 0IN;WIDTH:44.24%;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="1" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="PADDING:0IN 0IN 0IN 0IN;WIDTH:2.62%;">
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="1" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="23%" COLSPAN="5" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="PADDING:0IN 0IN 0IN 0IN;WIDTH:23.62%;">
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="1" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:8.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">

<A NAME="eolPage29"></A>
<BR CLEAR="ALL" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS;">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
<A HREF="#A16-4734_110K_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS" TITLE="CLICK TO GO TO TABLE OF CONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.3PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Diagnostic Services Revenues.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; Diagnostic services revenues are generated from providing DNA-based genomic testing services primarily in the areas of miscarriage analysis, PGS tests and postnatal development disorders in children.&#160; The key drivers and metrics relating to the change in diagnostic services revenues were as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_6"></A>
<TABLE BORDER="0" CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="89%" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE;MARGIN-LEFT:20.15PT;">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="58%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="PADDING:0IN 0IN 0IN 0IN;WIDTH:58.4%;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="1" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="PADDING:0IN 0IN 0IN 0IN;WIDTH:2.72%;">
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="1" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:1.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</B>
</P>

</P>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<HR SIZE="1" WIDTH="25%" NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="COLOR:BLACK;">
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .05IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	(1)&nbsp;&nbsp;includes prenatal, miscarriage analysis and PGS microarray tests
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.3PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, total billable tests and total diagnostic services revenues increased by 29% and 26%, respectively, compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.&#160; Driving the increase in billable tests and diagnostic services revenues was the increase in reproductive health (previously referred to as &#147;prenatal&#148;) microarray test volumes, which increased by 40% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.&#160; We believe this reflects the commercialization strategies and focus of our sales force, which have emphasized reproductive health microarray diagnostics testing over traditional genomics testing.&#160; While this has led to a higher concentration of reproductive health microarray tests as a percentage of total tests performed in 2015 compared to 2014, changes in payor mix coupled with non-coverage determinations by certain payors regarding our miscarriage analysis microarray test resulted in slightly lower average net revenue per test performed, thereby resulting in a lower percentage increase in total diagnostic services revenues compared to the increase in diagnostic testing volumes
</FONT>
	.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.3PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<FONT STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	Diagnostic services revenues also include adjustments relating to our revenue recognition policy of periodically adjusting our estimate for contractual allowances for revenues from non-contracted payors as well as from receiving cash payments in excess of amounts previously recognized for services revenues.
</FONT>
	For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, net positive revenue adjustments were $580,000 and $381,000, respectively.&#160; Because approximately 68% of our diagnostic revenues are billed to non-contracted, third-party payors, it is likely that we will be required to make adjustments to accounting estimates with respect to contractual allowances in the future, which may positively or adversely affect our revenues and results of operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Royalties.&#160;
</FONT>
</I>
	In 2010, we entered into an exclusive licensing agreement with CustomArray,&nbsp;Inc. (&#147;CA&#148;), a private company located in Washington State, for certain of our patents and intellectual property developed as part of our prior microarray manufacturing business.&#160; This agreement requires CA to pay us royalties as a percentage of their gross revenues, not less than $25,000 per quarter.&#160; CA&#146;s actual sales were nearly equivalent in 2015 compared to 2014.&#160; It is uncertain whether in future periods, CA&#146;s revenues will increase, continue at current levels or return to the minimum contractual amounts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Cost of Services.
</FONT>
</I>
	Cost of services relating to our diagnostic tests performed include direct materials such as microarray slides, reagents and related laboratory materials, direct laboratory labor (wages and benefits), allocation of administrative overhead and stock-compensation expenses.&nbsp;&nbsp; Increases in cost of services were due primarily to the increased diagnostic testing volumes previously discussed.&#160; Non-cash stock compensation expenses were not significant for the years presented.&#160; See Note 2 to our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report for a detailed description of the amounts of non-cash stock compensation expense recognized for the periods presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_7"></A>

</FONT>
	(dollars in thousands):
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="52%" VALIGN="TOP" BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="BACKGROUND:#CCEEFF;PADDING:0IN 0IN 0IN 0IN;WIDTH:52.12%;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT 10.1PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.1PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	General and administrative

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.3PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Research and Development.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; These expenses include labor (wages, benefits and non-cash stock compensation expenses) and laboratory supply costs associated with investigating and validating new tests and technology platforms, costs to maintain and improve our existing suite of diagnostic tests offered and process improvement projects.&#160; Prior to launching a new test or technology, or modifying an existing test, appropriate clinical trials and extensive laboratory validations, consistent with the various regulations that govern our industry, must be performed.&#160; These costs are classified as research and development for all periods presented.&#160; For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, research and development expenses decreased from 2014 due primarily to increased focus on commercial operations and reduced new-test development activities compared with prior periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
	29
<A NAME="A16-4734_110K_HTM_PB_29_122839_141">
</A>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<HR SIZE="3" WIDTH="100%" NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="COLOR:#010101;">
</DIV>
</DIV>
<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='29',FILE='C:\JMS\105568\16-4734-1\TASK7786517\4734-1-BM.HTM',USER='105568',CD='FEB 18 07:02 2016' -->
<A NAME="eolPage30"></A>
<BR CLEAR="ALL" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS;">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
<A HREF="#A16-4734_110K_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS" TITLE="CLICK TO GO TO TABLE OF CONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Sales and Marketing.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; These expenses include salaries and wages associated with our sales force and marketing resources, sales commissions and other expenses associated with promotional and advertising efforts as well as non-cash stock compensation expenses.&#160; For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, sales and marketing expenses increased from 2014 due primarily to increased headcount in sales representatives as well as increased marketing and promotional related activities.&#160; Non-cash stock compensation expenses were not significant for the years presented.&#160; See Note 2 to our consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report for a detailed description of the amounts of non-cash stock compensation expense recognized for the periods presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	General and Administrative.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; These expenses include compensation and benefit costs of our administrative staff, client billing and collections, information technology, executive management, human resources and accounting personnel, as well as facilities-related costs, insurance, legal, audit and other professional services. General and administrative expenses decreased from 2014 to 2015 due primarily to decreased litigation expenses, where we incurred $2.2 million of litigation-related costs and expenses during 2014 compared to only $114,000 in 2015.&#160; Partially offsetting the decrease in litigation expenses were increases to general and administrative salaries from increased headcount, increased investor relations expenses and increased recruiting costs.&#160; Also included in general and administrative expenses are non-cash stock-based compensation expenses, which were $594,000 and $444,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.&#160; Changes to stock-based compensation expenses are driven by timing of when stock-based awards are granted compared to when older awards become fully vested or expire due to forfeitures, as well as by the valuations attributed to individual awards at the time they are granted.&#160; See Note 2 to our consolidated interim financial statements included elsewhere in this report for a detailed description of the amounts of non-cash stock compensation expense recognized for the periods presented.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Impairment of cost-basis investment.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; During the third quarter of 2015, management determined that the carrying value of a cost-basis investment in the stock of a privately held company was impaired, resulting in a one-time, non-cash impairment charge of $97,000 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. There were no such charges in the 2014 comparable periods.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">

</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Warrant Derivatives Gains and Modification Charge
</FONT>
</I>
	.&#160; This activity represents the net gains or charges recognized from mark-to-market adjustments of certain Series&nbsp;A Warrants to their estimated fair values as of each balance sheet date or when the Series&nbsp;A Warrants are exercised.&#160; Prior to June&nbsp;2014 (the &#147;Modification Date&#148;), the Series&nbsp;A Warrants issued to Series&nbsp;A Investors contained full ratchet anti-dilution, which required us to treat them as derivative financial instruments to be recorded at fair value at each reporting date, with the corresponding adjustment reflected as a non-operating gain or charge in the consolidated statements of operations.&#160; We valued the Series&nbsp;A Warrants using the Monte-Carlo simulation method using the following assumptions immediately prior to the Modification Date:&#160; (i)&nbsp;closing stock price and Series&nbsp;A Warrant contractual exercise price; (ii)&nbsp;term to expiration commensurate with the individual Series&nbsp;A Warrant terms of 3.8 years; (iii)&nbsp;historical volatilities commensurate with the term of the Series&nbsp;A Warrants of 129.6%; (iv)&nbsp;risk-free interest rates commensurate with the term of the Series&nbsp;A Warrants of 1.2%; and (v)&nbsp;simulated anti-dilution impact assuming various probabilities that we will raise additional capital by issuing equity securities at prices above or below the current contractual Series&nbsp;A Warrant exercise prices during the Series&nbsp;A Warrant terms.&#160; The result of this valuation simulation was to value the remaining Series&nbsp;A Warrants held by Series&nbsp;A Investors at $281,000 as of the Modification Date.&#160; As a result, warrant derivative gains of $152,000 were recognized, and the remaining $281,000 was reclassified to additional paid-in capital.&#160; As a result of a similar valuation analysis performed during the quarter ended March&nbsp;31, 2014, the combined warrant derivative gains recognized in our consolidated statements of operations and the amount of warrant derivative liabilities reclassified to stockholders&#146; equity resulting from Series&nbsp;A Warrant exercises for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 was $152,000 and $416,000, respectively.&#160; The additional Series&nbsp;A Warrants to purchase 1,687 shares of common stock issued to the Series&nbsp;A Investors as consideration for agreeing to the modification of the Series&nbsp;A Warrants to remove the full ratchet anti-dilution provisions were valued using the Black-Scholes valuation model, using the following assumptions as of the Modification Date:&#160; (i)&nbsp;closing stock price and Series&nbsp;A Warrant contractual exercise price; (ii)&nbsp;term to expiration commensurate with the individual Series&nbsp;A Warrant terms of 3.8 years; (iii)&nbsp;historical volatility commensurate with the term of the Series&nbsp;A Warrants of 129.6%; and (iv)&nbsp;risk-free interest rates commensurate with the term of the Series&nbsp;A Warrants of 1.2%.&#160; The resulting valuation of $44,000 was recognized as a non-operating charge in our consolidated statement of operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>

	30
<A NAME="A16-4734_110K_HTM_PB_30_123127_7608">
</A>
</P>

	At December&nbsp;31, 2015, cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments totaled $3.9 million, compared to $5.2 million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.&#160; Cash is held primarily in general checking accounts as well as in money market mutual funds backed by U.S. government securities.&#160; Short-term investments are comprised primarily of certificates of deposits issued by U.S. financial institutions.&#160; Working capital was $5.4 million and $6.6 million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.&#160; The primary reason for the decrease in working capital was due to higher cash balances at December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to 2015, driven by operating, investing and financing activities described below.

<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="BOTTOM" BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="BACKGROUND:#CCEEFF;PADDING:0IN 0IN 0IN 0IN;WIDTH:3.28%;">

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Operating Activities.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; Higher cash inflows from improved cash collections coupled with lower litigation costs during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 resulted in lower cash used in operating activities compared to 2014.&#160; Our overall cash reimbursement was 93% of total revenues in 2015 compared to 92% in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Investing Activities.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; The increase in net cash flows from investing activities was due to significant purchases of available-for-sale short-term investments made during 2014 that were not repeated in 2015, coupled with sales of certain available-for-sale short-term investments in 2015 that did not occur in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Financing Activities.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; The increase in net cash flows from financing activities was due primarily to the $4.7 million of net proceeds received in February&nbsp;2015 from the Series&nbsp;E Financing, compared to proceeds from Series&nbsp;A Warrant exercises during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 that were nearly offset by Series&nbsp;D offering related costs that were paid during the same period.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Future Liquidity.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; We have a history of incurring net losses and net operating cash flow deficits.&#160; We are also deploying new technologies and continue to develop commercial technologies and services.&#160; We believe that our cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 will be sufficient to meet our expected cash requirements for current operations into the third quarter of 2016.&#160; In order for us to continue as a going concern beyond this point and to ultimately achieve profitability, we may be required to obtain capital from external sources, increase revenues and reduce operating costs.&#160; However, there can be no assurance that our operations will become profitable or that external sources of financing, including the issuance of debt and/or equity securities, will be available at times and at terms acceptable to us, or at all.&#160; The issuance of additional equity or convertible debt securities will also cause dilution to our stockholders.&#160; If external financing sources are not available or are inadequate to fund our operations, we will be required to reduce operating costs, including research projects and personnel, which could jeopardize our future strategic initiatives and business plans.&#160; See Notes 1 and 13 to the consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this report for additional discussion of these matters.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
	31
<A NAME="A16-4734_110K_HTM_PB_31_123337_8146">
</A>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<HR SIZE="3" WIDTH="100%" NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" STYLE="COLOR:#010101;">

	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;">
	Capital Requirements.
</FONT>
</I>
	&#160; We may also encounter unforeseen difficulties that may deplete our capital resources more rapidly than anticipated.&#160; As a result, we may be required to seek additional funding through equity, debt or other external financing, and there can be no assurance that additional funding will be available on favorable terms, in a timely fashion or at all.&#160; At this time, we have no significant commitments for capital expenditures in 2016 or beyond.&#160; However, our long-term capital requirements could be substantial and the adequacy of available funds will depend upon many factors, including:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	the costs of commercialization activities, including sales and marketing costs and capital equipment;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	competing technological developments;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	the creation and formation of strategic partnerships;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	variability in third-party reimbursement for our diagnostic tests;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	the costs associated with leasing and improving our Irvine, California facility; and
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT .5IN;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:-.25IN;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="SYMBOL" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#183;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
	other factors that may not be within our control.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we did not have any significant off-balance sheet arrangements, as defined in Item 303(a)(4)(ii)&nbsp;of Regulation S-K promulgated by the SEC.&#160; We have entered into an operating lease for our laboratory space and corporate offices, totaling approximately 12,200 square feet, expiring in early 2020.&#160; We have no significant commitments for capital expenditures for 2016 or beyond.&#160; We have executed eleven capital leases totaling $310,000 for certain laboratory and IT-related equipment, with lease payments continuing through May&nbsp;2019.
</FONT>
</P>

<A NAME="A16-4734_110K_HTM_ITEM9A_CONTROLSANDPROCEDURES_124005">

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Conclusion Regarding the Effectiveness of Disclosure Controls and Procedures
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	Under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our principal executive officer and principal financial officer, we conducted an evaluation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as such term is defined under Rules&nbsp;13a-15(e)&nbsp;and 15d-15(e)&nbsp;promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.&#160; Based on this evaluation, our principal executive officer and our principal financial officer concluded that, as of the end of the period covered by this annual report, our disclosure controls and procedures were effective to ensure that the information required to be disclosed by us in the reports that we file or submit under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is accumulated and communicated to management, including our chief executive officer and chief financial officer, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure, and that such information is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods prescribed by the SEC.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

	Table of Contents
</A>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;">
<B>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Management&#146;s Report on Internal Controls Over Financial Reporting
</FONT>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal controls over financial reporting, as such term is defined in Exchange Act Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f)&nbsp;and 15d-15(f).&#160; Under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our principal executive officer and principal financial officer, we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal controls over financial reporting based on the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (or &#147;COSO&#148;) in Internal Control-Integrated Framework (specifically, the 2013 Framework).&#160; Based on our evaluation under the framework in Internal Control - Integrated Framework, our management concluded that our internal controls over financial reporting were effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:17.4PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	There has been no change in our internal controls over financial reporting that occurred during the fiscal quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 that has materially affected, or is reasonably expected to materially affect, our internal controls over financial reporting.
</FONT>
</P>

	&#160;&#160;

	Member of the Audit Committee
</I>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&#134;
</FONT>

	Member of the Compensation Committee
</I>
<BR>
	^
<FONT SIZE="1" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:3.0PT;">
	&#160;&#160;&#160;
</FONT>
<I>
	Member of the Nominating and Governance Committee
</I>

<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<B>
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Mark McDonough
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	has served as our President, Chief Executive Officer and a member of our Board since March&nbsp;2013. From August&nbsp;2012 to March&nbsp;2013, Mr.&nbsp;McDonough served as our Chief Commercial Officer. Mr.&nbsp;McDonough has over 18 years of experience in diagnostic healthcare and life sciences. Prior to joining us, Mr.&nbsp;McDonough was Vice President of Sales and Service at Pathwork Diagnostics, a venture capital backed molecular diagnostic company, from September&nbsp;2008 to August&nbsp;2012. He also served in an executive capacity at Dianon, a division of Laboratory Corporation of America, from September&nbsp;2007 to July&nbsp;2008 and at Laboratory Corporation of America, a public laboratory services company, from July&nbsp;2008 to September&nbsp;2008. From January&nbsp;2002 to September&nbsp;2007, Mr.&nbsp;McDonough held various positions at US LABS, a Pathology services company that eventually became a division of LabCorp, a public company, ultimately becoming Vice President of Sales. From May&nbsp;2001 to January&nbsp;2002, Mr.&nbsp;McDonough was a Sales executive with EMC Corporation, a data storage company, and from August&nbsp;1997 to May&nbsp;2001, he held various positions of increasing responsibility with Ventana Medical Systems, a capital equipment, cancer diagnostics company. Prior to entering the healthcare industry, Mr.&nbsp;McDonough was a ranking officer in the United States Navy for six years where he served as Navigator of the USS Fletcher (DD 992). Mr.&nbsp;McDonough received a Bachelor&#146;s Degree in Finance from Miami University&#151;Ohio. We believe Mr.&nbsp;McDonough&#146;s qualifications to serve on our Board include his commercial expertise as an executive, his technical depth in microarray technology and cancer diagnostics, his strategic vision, and familiarity with senior executives in industry as well as with venture capitalists.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<B>
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Scott R. Burell
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	has served as our Chief Financial Officer, Secretary and Treasurer since November&nbsp;2006.&#160; He successfully led the split-off of the Company in 2007 from its former parent, has led several successful public and private debt and equity financing transactions as well as the Company&#146;s reorganization in 2010.&#160; Prior to this, Mr.&nbsp;Burell had served as our Vice President of Finance since November&nbsp;2001 and as our Controller from February&nbsp;2001 to November&nbsp;2001. From May&nbsp;1999 to first joining CombiMatrix in February&nbsp;2001, Mr.&nbsp;Burell was the Controller for Network Commerce,&nbsp;Inc., a publicly traded technology and information infrastructure company located in Seattle.&#160; Prior to this, Mr.&nbsp;Burell spent 9 years with Arthur Andersen&#146;s Audit and Business Advisory practice in Seattle.&#160; During his tenure in public accounting, Mr.&nbsp;Burell worked with many clients, both public and private, in the high-tech and healthcare markets, and was involved in numerous public offerings, spin-offs, mergers and acquisitions.&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Burell obtained his Washington state CPA license in 1992 and is a certified public accountant (currently inactive). He holds Bachelor of Science degrees in Accounting and Business Finance from Central Washington University.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">

<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<BR CLEAR="ALL" STYLE="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS;">
<DIV STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN;">
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
<A HREF="#A16-4734_110K_HTM_TABLEOFCONTENTS" TITLE="CLICK TO GO TO TABLE OF CONTENTS">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<B>
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	R. Judd Jessup
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	has served on our Board since August&nbsp;2010, has served as Chairman of our Board since March&nbsp;2013 and served as our President and Chief Executive Officer from August&nbsp;2010 to March&nbsp;2013. Mr.&nbsp;Jessup has over 35 years of experience in the healthcare and managed care industries. Most recently, he was Chief Executive Officer of US LABS, a national laboratory which provides cancer diagnostics and genetic testing services, from 2002 to 2005. He has extensive background in the managed care industry having served as President of the Health Plans Division for FHP International from 1994 to 1996 as well as President of TakeCare,&nbsp;Inc., a publicly traded HMO operating in California, Colorado,&nbsp;Illinois and Ohio until it was sold to FHP. Mr.&nbsp;Jessup currently serves on the board of directors of Corvel Corporation, a publicly traded company. He served on the board of directors of NovaMed,&nbsp;Inc., a publicly traded company, from November&nbsp;1998 until May&nbsp;2011. We believe Mr.&nbsp;Jessup&#146;s qualifications to serve on our Board include his significant executive experience with the strategic, financial, and operational requirements of large health care organizations, including serving as an audit committee chair.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<B>
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Robert E. Hoffman
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	has served on our Board since July&nbsp;2013. He is the Chief Financial Officer of AnaptysBio,&nbsp;Inc., a privately held biopharmaceutical company, where he has served since July&nbsp;2015.&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman was the Senior Vice President, Finance and Chief Financial Officer of Arena Pharmaceuticals,&nbsp;Inc., a publicly traded biopharmaceutical company, until July&nbsp;2015 where he had served in various finance and accounting roles since 1997, except that from March&nbsp;2011 to August&nbsp;2011, Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman served as Chief Financial Officer for Polaris Group, a privately held drug development company.&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman is a member of the business and financial advisory board of Innovus Pharmaceuticals, a publicly traded emerging pharmaceuticals company.&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman also serves as a member of the Financial Accounting Standards Board&#146;s Small Business Advisory Committee and the steering committee of the Association of Bioscience Financial Officers. Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman is also a member and a former director and President of the San Diego Chapter of Financial Executives International. Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman holds a bachelor&#146;s degree in business administration from St. Bonaventure University, and is licensed as a C.P.A. (inactive) in the State of California.&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman is also a member of the board of directors of MabVax Therapeutics Holdings,&nbsp;Inc. and Kura Oncology,&nbsp;Inc. We believe Mr.&nbsp;Hoffman&#146;s qualifications to serve on our Board include his experience as an executive of a drug development company and knowledge of financial accounting in the medical technology field.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<B>
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Scott Gottlieb, M.D.
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	has served on our Board since January&nbsp;2009. Dr.&nbsp;Gottlieb is currently a Resident Fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. Dr.&nbsp;Gottlieb is also a Clinical Assistant Professor at the NYU School of Medicine. From 2005 until 2007, Dr.&nbsp;Gottlieb served at the Food and Drug Administration (&#147;FDA&#148;) as Deputy Commissioner for Medical and Scientific Affairs and before that, from 2003 until 2004, as Senior Advisor for Medical Technology to the FDA Commissioner and as the FDA&#146;s Director of Medical Policy Development. He left the FDA in the spring of 2004 to work on implementation of the new Medicare Drug Benefit as a Senior Adviser to the Administrator of Medicare and Medicaid Services, where he supported the agency&#146;s policy work on quality improvement and coverage and payment decision making, particularly related to new medical technologies. Dr.&nbsp;Gottlieb currently serves on the board of directors of Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals. Dr.&nbsp;Gottlieb completed his residency in internal medicine at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York City and is a graduate of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and of Wesleyan University in Connecticut. We believe Dr.&nbsp;Gottlieb&#146;s qualifications to serve on our Board include his experience as a Wall Street analyst, practicing physician, and most importantly in senior roles in the U.S. government, including his former role as Deputy Commissioner of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. CombiMatrix operates in business markets where regulation and regulatory strategy need to be considered and Dr.&nbsp;Gottlieb&#146;s insights are beneficial to us.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;TEXT-INDENT:.25IN;">
<B>
<I>
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;FONT-STYLE:ITALIC;FONT-WEIGHT:BOLD;">
	Jeremy M. Jones
</FONT>
</I>
</B>
	has served on our Board since November&nbsp;2012. He is the Chairman of On Assignment,&nbsp;Inc., a publicly traded professional staffing firm, where he has served as a director since May&nbsp;1995. Mr.&nbsp;Jones has been an investor and business development consultant since February&nbsp;1998. From 1987 to 1995, Mr.&nbsp;Jones was Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Homedco Group,&nbsp;Inc., a home healthcare services company, which became publicly traded in 1991. Homedco merged into Apria Healthcare Group,&nbsp;Inc. in 1995 and from 1995 through January&nbsp;1998, Mr.&nbsp;Jones was Chief Executive Officer and Chairman of the Board of Apria Healthcare Group,&nbsp;Inc., which also provided home healthcare services. Mr.&nbsp;Jones served as Chairman of the Board of Byram Healthcare Centers, a provider of retail medical supplies, from February&nbsp;1999 until its sale in March&nbsp;of 2008. Mr.&nbsp;Jones was a director for Access Point Medical from May&nbsp;2004 to December&nbsp;2005. Mr.&nbsp;Jones was a director of US LABS from November&nbsp;2003 through February&nbsp;2005. From July&nbsp;2003 to January&nbsp;2011, Mr.&nbsp;Jones served as Chairman of LifeCare Solutions,&nbsp;Inc., a provider of integrated home healthcare products and services. Mr.&nbsp;Jones became a Director of the Hoag Hospital Foundation, Newport Beach, California as of July&nbsp;2014. Mr.&nbsp;Jones holds a bachelor&#146;s degree in business administration from the University of Iowa. We believe Mr.&nbsp;Jones&#146; qualifications to serve on our Board include his significant executive experience with the strategic, financial, and operational requirements of public health care organizations, including serving as Chairman for those organizations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
<FONT SIZE="2" FACE="TIMES NEW ROMAN" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;">
	&nbsp;
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-SIZE:10.0PT;MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;TEXT-ALIGN:CENTER;">
	34
<A NAME="A16-4734_110K_HTM_PB_34_114605_7056">
</A>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="MARGIN:0IN 0IN .0001PT;">
